ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I expected this course to teach me how to understand financial concepts, not how to do them. While it is necessary to know a little bit of doing, it felt like we weren't focusing enough on the theory and concepts, and spending too much time on the details of how to manipulate financial statements. Since most of us won't be going into those roles, what would be more helpful is learning how to INTERPRET information.

A lot of people complained about the material being presented too fast, but it seems to me this course was meant to be a survey so you now have a familiarity with the material which it accomplished. I don't know the material inside and out by any means but there were several 3 credit semester long courses crammed into 1 credit, so I wouldn't expect to. At least now I know where to find some of the information in the future.

This course a farce. It is designed such that the student is not expected to retain knowledge or master the content in any meaningful way, and that the professor is not expected to teach. That a graduate course could have such low standards disgusts me, and that a faculty person at Yale could be receiving payment coming in part from my tuition for such exceedingly lazy performance is a discredit to the school. If I had any conviction that Yale FES or professor Burke were committed to improving the course, I would offer suggestions in the boxes below, but my only conclusion is that this class serves the purely transactional purpose of granting students a credit and an easy pass in a topic that looks good on a resume, and granting the professor a paycheck and a chance to 'teach' at Yale. The single most negative experience of my time at FES.
Some things were breezed over so quickly I didn't get how they fit in to other parts of the class - like what are stock - how do they actually work?
This course should be a 3 credits course. It is not effective in a 1cr mode.
Class was great but too fast!! Also, because it's at the end of the day it's hard to concentrate and keep up with the pace.

I was extremely disappointed with this course overall. The professor was not good at explaining concepts and even though she had powerpoint presentations 75+ slides long and lecture notes and in-class exercises, she still managed to leave out vital steps for completing the homework assignments. There was even inaccurate information in the lecture notes. On one assignment for instance, there was an example of how figure out a certain calculation in the lecture notes but when the exact same calculation came up in the homework, I was informed (by the T.A.s!) that I had done it wrong and there was another step that had been completely left out. She uses examples in class that seem almost purposely misleading. On one of the first assignments the example she had used lead me to understand one thing (specifically that the numbers don't show up on the income statement until a transaction is considered completed by both parties), while the T.A.s again had to clarify that actually it meant something different (that even if one party doesn't actually pay but the other party completed the work, then the transaction is considered 'complete' and the party that completed the work gets to count it on their income statement). This would have been easy to fix in class and I felt intentionally misled. Letting students "figure things out" on the homework is one thing, being so bad at explaining things that the assignments are impossible to complete on our own or intentionally trying to be tricky is something different, and not okay.

Mixed feelings. Huge course (60 students), late evening in a dark room in Sage, taken my final semester. I am usually motivated to soak up knowledge in all courses, and couldn't muster up energy in this one. That could be a reflection of my unfamiliarity and disinterest with the subject matter, the instructional structure, or my own personal motivation. I did not get much out of this class, but I felt like I should take it. Homework was stressful (despite beyond-fantastic and very dedicated TAs). Pace of class was rapid-fire: far too fast to take notes. Felt more like a speed language course than a conceptual foundational class at times, but again, I only put in minimal effort. I recommend: if you do take it, decide beforehand how much time you'll put in. Consider doing a self-paced course instead if you're like me. But, since you're taking the effort to read through these evaluations, I bet you're very motivated and will get a lot out of the professor's vast knowledge of the subject and thorough lectures.
The class moved way too fast to truly understand the concepts taught, explanations were confusing as well.

8) Professor Burke covered a lot of material in a short amount of time. She is clearly very knowledgable but didn't always give the fullest or clearest explanations. This could have been due to the amount of material she was trying to fit in. Overall the explanations were good but not quite as sharp as some of these concepts were covered in other classes I've taken.

I expected this course to provide a big picture understanding of basic financial concepts (as the course title led me to believe). Instead, it felt like an overly detail-oriented accounting or bookkeeping course. The pace of teaching was way too fast for an introductory level course, and the information was very poorly communicated. There were way too many slides that did not convey information clearly. I rarely felt prepared to complete the homework assignments and felt I left this class without any useful knowledge that I had hoped to gain. I would have preferred to take a full semester course on finance at FES.

In general about the course: The course is on-point, all substance, no fluff. Bout the instructor: Professor Maureen Burke is knowledgeable, enthusiastic, clear, concise and engaging. A wonderful educator.

This material is so vital to so many MEM students seeking an introduction to finance. But the instructor presents material way too quickly and uses far too complex examples before anyone has a chance to begin to understand the material. This course would be better served as a full 3 credit course, and SHOULD NOT take place during the final weeks of the year.

This course includes more accounting content than finance. I would call this course "Introduction to accounting". At any time the course treated environmental issues of any kind. Rather, the course goes through general cases but not environmental ones. The instructor goes very fast, at least in my opinion that I had any background in accounting. In some situations, the instructor did not have enough time to explain adequately important concepts since she overestimated the amount of information. Thus she went too fast in important concepts in order to be able to cover all the content she had planned fro the session. There is one assignment per week.
There was too much material to be covered in a six week time period. The lessons were rushed and I left the class feeling like I did not know much more than when I started.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The TAs were helpful
that it was half a semester course
good way to learn new concepts and vocabulary
The examples provided and exercises were very helpful.

The most useful parts of the course were the in-class exercises, the lecture notes and the assignments we had to work through. That said, the lecture notes were not well-organized and were not complete. The concepts reviewed in class and in the lecture notes did not prepare you to actually complete the assignments. The assignments themselves were useful but unnecessarily difficult because the concepts in them had not been well-explained by the professor at any point. It was as though assignments had been prepared with the expectation that we would just guess the right way to do them. It's one thing to throw a challenge in or something not explicitly covered, it's another thing to completely leave out vital information that is needed in order to get the correct answer. I will also point out that multiple times the T.A.s and the professor didn't necessarily agree on the answers to the questions for the homework. Or the T.A.'s would point something out or have us do something for the homework that wasn't incorporated into the answers given by the professor. In other words, the T.A.s seemed to have a better grasp of the concepts and were better at explaining them.
Maureen was great at explaining concepts

Learning basic accounting skills. Professor Burke covers a range of basic topics that seem very helpful to know. She also learned everyone's name immediately, which was really nice and made the large class feel smaller.
Provided an overview of the basics of finance.
A surprisingly large amount of on target information, clearly presented in a logical progression.
The written class notes explaining the material.

It is a course where students without any knowledge in accounting can grasp at least some superficial concepts of accounting. For a more complete accounting course, I would recommend to take SOM courses.

The combination of course materials and Ms Burke explanation was the best part of the course. She keep repeating the key terms that we have to know on financial management to make us familiar with the terms.
It teaches you something new

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The pace is WAY too fast, and there's too much of a focus on doing the calculations, rather than learning how to interpret information
material was too intense too fast. should be reduced to really learn the material.
None, I think the course did exactly what it was designed to do.
Need more explanation of what all the numbers mean. I could do the calculations in the homework but often was unsure what it all meant in the end
Timing.
Please update your slides, case study, background reading etc. to current times. Consider teaching this class at a different time of the day.
If the class was a little slower it would be better.
The course is too fast. the material is very useful but the pace is impossible.

Sitting and listening for two hours to a professor read off of powerpoint slides is never and never has been a good way for any human being to learn. That's exactly what class time was and it was a completely waste of time. A more useful exercise would be to provide us with the lecture notes beforehand, spend 10-15 minutes going over a short lecture boiled down to the basic, important concepts, and then spent the rest of the time working through problem sets. I would have gotten the exact same thing out of the class and wouldn't have wasted three times as much time on it. I really can't stress enough how useless it is to spend class-time (two hours!!!) reading off of powerpoint slides.

The course seemed very disorganized. The lectures did not flow well, the instructor's teaching style did not translate information well to students, and slides were fairly incoherent. The assignments were largely busy work and didn't provide a great deal of additional understanding.
The Excel spreadsheets could be very confusing in terms of understanding what cells we could change and which ones were supposed to be left alone
A more thorough description of all topics would be helpful, it felt like the entire class was very rushed. I struggled to keep up with the material.
It might be possible to make the slideshows shorter or less cluttered to help clarify some of the conceptual explanations.
Could be a semester long course with more concepts and depth.
It would be good to have more samples, in print, concerning how to approach the homework problems. This is a minor concern.

We went way too fast for beginners. The homework was too technical for my level of understanding. I got lost so early on in the course that I got nothing out of the homework because I had no foundation to build off of to even attempt the homework using my own brain without asking the TAs enough questions to try and piece something together and still not understand what I did.
Material presented too quickly, with too complex examples.

Improve the organization of what to include in each session, in order to plan the class' contents realistically and not overestimate. I would include cases of different types in order to understand better how to classify the components of the projects.

Overall was good unless it only a one credits course meaning that a lot of materials have to be covered in a very short period of time. Some times the instructor was too fast to cover the class materials.

The course goes too fast for someone who hasn't taken finance before. Also, the professor just reads PowerPoint slides, which could be done by students themselves online. Also the assignments are waaaay too long for a 1 credit class!

Go slower when explaining an excel formula. Also, answers in ppt are not as helpful when they are taken from an excel doc since the formula is lost and it is difficult to see how the answer was determined. Review of homework was too fast for more difficult assignments.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: n/a
Yes, the labs were good for going over homework questions (not just with TAs, but also with peers)
N/A
During a portion of each class, students worked on assigned problem sets. We could work alone, in pairs or in groups. The choice worked well.
The instructor offered (non-mandatory) sessions for students to ask doubts/for further information. I could not attend to any of them because of time conflict so I can not evaluate the sessions.
The TA section was very effective. It helped us on how to apply the financial techniques for our homeworks

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am interested in ecosystem and conservation finance and assumed this would be a good introductory course to basic financial concepts and language.
I will be taking finance classes next term, so this was a great introduction!
Helpful to learn skills for job purposes after graduation.
What a perfect fit! I knew I needed finance background, and this was the perfect introduction.
The course material is crucial to any MEM student who wants to work in the private sector.

I would recommend this course for students that want to have limited knowledge of accounting and are willing to spend additional time for self-instructing for a better understanding of the course's concepts. For students that want to be an entrepreneur I would suggest to take SOM courses.
I have no financial background and this course gave me a foundation for finance especially on project and company valuation.

This course was a way for me to learn certain aspects of financial management that are needed for running nonprofits and other organizations (such as accounting) without the need for taking a deep-dive class at SOM.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: i'm hoping to get a broad understanding of financial concepts.
I have a limited background in finance and math. I took this course to get a better understanding of basic financial and accounting concepts.
Want basic into and vocabulary
Because I have very little background in the financial concepts
I thought it would be good to get a little bit better understanding of finance and accounting, since I have no experience with it.
For a basic understanding of financial concepts.
My future career field in conservation, or business-environment nexus, will require knowledge of these concepts
Basic accounting/finance skills seem important and relevant to any career path.
Needed to learn basic concepts of finance.
Knowledge of finance is critical in most careers, and the environment is no exception.
I just wanted some background knowledge on finances but I think all I learned was what assets, liabilities, and equity were.
To add financial savvy to my job skills and prepare for work after graduation.
I wanted to have an introduction to finance and understand the jargon of this area. The course turn out to be accounting instead of finance.
To have an exposure and introduce myself to key aspect of finance.
To try and have a better grasp on the business side of environmental work, since that is such a popular topic at FES.
I took it just to expand my horizons
I felt that this course would add value to me as a potential employee and give me knowledge that would be useful later in starting an organization or initiative.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I was hoping to get an overview of financial terms, concepts, and basic information that I need to know. I feel like we got too far into the weeds, rather than focusing on important higher-level concepts
i didn't really learn much because it was too fast
Yes but the title of the course gives the impression that there would be more discussion and application of concepts to environmental issues
Sort of - almost covered too much and would like to have hammered in on a few small things
No.
To an extent.
No, because essentially i did not learn much due to the fast pace.

Absolutely not. I was extremely disappointed. It was a waste of time and it was extremely frustrating. Also, the title of the course is a bit misleading. It was a "Financial Concepts for Environmental Managers" course with a professor that explicitly told us she had no experience with or knowledge about organizations like non-profits or government - which happens to be where a lot of environmental managers go. She couldn't even say how they might be different from private business firms.
No. I left the class with very little new knowledge.
Yes, I have some key take-aways
Yes
Yes.
Yes, very well.
No. I just wanted some background knowledge on finances but I think all I learned was what assets, liabilities, and equity were.
No. I would not recommend other students to take this course. I would recommend finding something at SOM or online.
Not as much as I wanted . I would have rather spend additional time to learn more about the course's main concepts but with the load of the other courses I was taking, I could not do this.
Yes it met my expectations.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Helped dissect the homework. The classes didn't seem to prepare us well for the homework.
N/A

As stated above: During a portion of each class, students worked on assigned problem sets. We could work alone, in pairs or in groups. The choice worked well. So there were no assigned group projects, but students had the opportunity to support each other and ask for support.
N/A
Group work helped to get the work done more efficiently and think through concepts with classmates.
Minimal group work, but in class working with a partner allowed for us to figure out the assignment together.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: This course goes very quickly, and the homework is stressful and somewhat difficult to keep up with. More useful if you'd like to learn how to manipulate financial information, less useful if you're hoping to gain some higher-level knowledge of the what and why of financials.
Be ready to put in a few hours a week for the assignments. Can sometimes seem like a lot for 1 credit but totally worth it in my opinion.
Do not take it.
Useful class, should be 3 credits and run an entire semester. Impossible for first-time learners of finance.

Don't take this course. It's a waste of time and hugely frustrating in a way that is completely unnecessary. If you actually want to learn something about finance, take a course at SOM. If you actually want to learn something about finance in environmental organizations, you might be SOL. If you just want to dip your toes into finance, pick up a "Finance for Dummies" book, you'll get just as much out of it and you won't waste so much time and energy. I'm saying this and I got a 3/3 on every homework, believe me, I didn't get much out of it.
Consider taking a different introductory finance class, like Forest and Ecosystem Finance or an SOM course.
Good intro course

This course is worth taking. It gives you what you'd expect from a 1-credit class: it isn't going to make you a finance whiz, but it is helpful for getting a basic understanding of some accounting and finance skills. Professor Burke is a good teacher and will throw a lot at you, but she's very good at going over the same concepts 2-4 times through the lectures and homeworks so that they have time to sink in.

If you lack finance background or have significant gaps in in your finance background, this is the proper introductory course to take. The material is all valuable and is presented well and in a logical progression.
Unless you have a background in finances or are very mathematically oriented you probably won't get anything out of this course unless something changes.
Don't take it unless it's offered at a different time and semester.

Take this course if you want to understand basic concepts of accounting. If you can organize yourself and allocate additional time to go through the course's content, you could gain a better understanding. If you want to be an entrepreneur do not take this course. Rather, take courses at SOM.
Take it!
It's a finance 101 course, and take it if you haven't learned about the basic concepts.
If you have taken finance courses before and are not bored by it you may enjoy this one, if not be careful about deciding to take this course!
